response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit and establish a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_6] This measure also requires the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. [CHUNK_7] Part III, which establishes the pilot program, shall be repealed on June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_22]",
  "appropriations": "There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_20] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment. [CHUNK_20] The appropriation also provides for the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program. [CHUNK_21]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The women's court pilot program shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary and will be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [CHUNK_12] The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [CHUNK_12] The program will implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices and employ gender-responsive programming. [CHUNK_13]",
  "agency_impact": "There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program, which shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [CHUNK_12] The judiciary is responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [CHUNK_13] This measure establishes one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the pilot program. [CHUNK_21]",
  "economic_impact": "The goal of the program is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [CHUNK_10] Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. [CHUNK_2] The services offered by the program are intended to address these areas, including trauma and mental health treatment, life-skills training, and housing support. [CHUNK_10, CHUNK_11]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit by codifying it within the Hawaii Revised Statutes. [CHUNK_30] It establishes a temporary two-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit, which sunsets on June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_23, CHUNK_35] The judiciary is required to submit a report of its findings and recommendations on the pilot program to the governor and legislature prior to the 2026 and 2027 regular sessions. [CHUNK_16]",
  "revenue_sources": "The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_19] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_21] No other revenue sources are identified in the provided documents. [CHUNK_19, CHUNK_21]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "This measure permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit, which will have ongoing fiscal implications beyond the six-year outlook. [CHUNK_6] For the two-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit, the Act appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026. [CHUNK_20] For fiscal year 2026-2027, the appropriation is $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_20] These funds are designated for mental health, substance abuse treatment, other services, and equipment for the pilot program. [CHUNK_20] The appropriations also fund one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [CHUNK_21] The pilot program is established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary. [CHUNK_12] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [CHUNK_12] The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [CHUNK_12] The pilot program is repealed on June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_22] Therefore, there are no further appropriations for the pilot program in this Act beyond fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_20, CHUNK_22]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided documents do not describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues. [CHUNK_19, CHUNK_20] The measure is funded by an appropriation from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_19] There is no indication that the program is intended to generate revenue. [CHUNK_19, CHUNK_20]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The appropriations for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027 include funding for equipment. [CHUNK_20] The bill appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2026-2027 for services and equipment. [CHUNK_20] No specific capital expenditure items are detailed in the Act. [CHUNK_20]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The permanent establishment of the women's court program in the first circuit will create ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the six-year outlook. [CHUNK_6] The women's court pilot program in the Kona division of the third circuit is temporary, as Part III of the Act is repealed on June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_22] Any long-term fiscal implications for a Women's Court in the Third Circuit would depend on future legislation based on the findings and recommendations from the pilot program's required reports. [CHUNK_16]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The primary update from the previous fiscal note is the inclusion of specific appropriation amounts, with the measure now appropriating $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027, replacing the prior version's unspecified sums. [CHUNK_32] The duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit was changed from three years to two years, with the sunset date moved to June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_31, CHUNK_35] The number of temporary positions funded by the bill has been reduced from two to one, establishing only a temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [CHUNK_32] The Judiciary is now explicitly required to be responsible for providing mental health services under the pilot program. [CHUNK_31] Additionally, language that would have required the Judiciary to submit a report on the need for pilot programs in other circuits was deleted. [CHUNK_33]"
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB727 CD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 727 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 1 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 2 C.D. 1 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that

OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai ʻ i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of

who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have

more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program

of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The

services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in

participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to: (1) Permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit; (2) Establish a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the

in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (3) Require the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's

reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. PART II SECTION 2. Chapter 603, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a new section to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " §603- Women's court program; first circuit. (a) There shall be established within the

program; first circuit. (a) There shall be established within the first circuit of the judiciary the women's court program. The program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration,

court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4)

including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing support. " PART III SECTION 3. (a) There shall be established within the third

SECTION 3. (a) There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot

be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. The pilot program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and

participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the pilot program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic

(3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing support. SECTION 4. The judiciary shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations, including any proposed legislation, on the

its findings and recommendations, including any proposed legislation, on the pilot program to the governor and legislature no later than forty days prior to the convening of the regular sessions of 2026 and 2027, regarding: (1) The status of the women's court pilot program; (2) The number of women accepted

women's court pilot program; (2) The number of women accepted into the women's court pilot program; (3) The number of women who were eligible to participate in the women's court pilot program but who could not be accepted into the pilot program because of pilot program limitations; (4) The number

pilot program because of pilot program limitations; (4) The number of women completing the women's court pilot program; (5) The number of women who were removed from the women's court pilot program; and (6) Recommendations as to whether the women's court pilot program should: (A) Continue as a pilot program;

court pilot program should: (A) Continue as a pilot program; (B) Expand to include additional participants; (C) Provide additional services; or (D) Be discontinued. SECTION 5. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 or so much thereof as may be

sum of $514,900 or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary

and the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program established pursuant to section 3 of this Act. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. PART IV SECTION 6. This

the purposes of this Act. PART IV SECTION 6. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025; provided that part III shall be repealed on June 30, 2027. Report Title: Judiciary; Women's Court Pilot Program; Reports; Appropriations Description: Permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit. Establishes

establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit. Establishes a temporary two-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. Requires reports. Establishes a temporary position. Appropriates funds. Sunsets 6/30/2027. (CD1) The summary description of legislation appearing on this page is for informational purposes only
legislation appearing on this page is for informational purposes only and is not legislation or evidence of legislative intent.

CCR58 CONFERENCE COMMITTEE REP. NO. 58 Honolulu, Hawaii , 2025 RE: H.B. No. 727 H.D. 1 S.D. 2 C.D. 1 Honorable Nadine K. Nakamura Speaker, House of Representatives Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular

D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madam and Sir: Your Committee on Conference on the disagreeing vote of the House of Representatives to the amendments proposed by the Senate in H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL

H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," having met, and after full and free discussion, has agreed to recommend and does recommend to the respective Houses the final passage of this bill in an amended form. The purpose of

of this bill in an amended form. The purpose of this measure is to (1) Make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent; (2) Establish and appropriate funds for a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; and (3) Require the

Kona division of the Third Circuit; and (3) Require the Judiciary to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Fifth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit. Your Committee on Conference

Hilo division of the Third Circuit. Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by: (1) Codifying the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit within the Hawaii Revised Statutes, rather than the Session Laws of Hawaii; (2) Requiring the Judiciary to be responsible for providing mental health services under

Judiciary to be responsible for providing mental health services under the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; (3) Changing the duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit from three years to two years; (4) Appropriating $514,900

Circuit from three years to two years; (4) Appropriating $514,900 for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 for fiscal year 2026-2027 for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the Women's Court Pilot

drug court probation supervisor position for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; (5) Deleting language that would have required the Judiciary to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court

the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Fifth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit; (6) Changing the effective date to July 1, 2025; (7) Changing the sunset date for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third

Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit to June 30, 2027; and (8) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. As affirmed by the record of votes of the managers of your Committee on Conference that is attached to this report,

your Committee on Conference that is attached to this report, your Committee on Conference is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Final Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 727, H.D.

in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, C.D. 1. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the managers: ON THE PART OF THE SENATE ON THE PART OF THE HOUSE ____________________________ KARL RHOADS Chair ____________________________ DAVID A. TARNAS Co-Chair ____________________________ LYNN DECOITE Co-Chair ____________________________ LISA KITAGAWA

overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

HB727_CD1_CCR58_.chunk_text: HB727 CD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 727 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 1 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 2 C.D. 1 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that

OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai ʻ i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of

who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have

more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program

of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The

services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in

participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to: (1) Permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit; (2) Establish a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the

in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (3) Require the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's

reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. PART II SECTION 2. Chapter 603, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a new section to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " §603- Women's court program; first circuit. (a) There shall be established within the

program; first circuit. (a) There shall be established within the first circuit of the judiciary the women's court program. The program shall implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices, employ gender-responsive programming, collaborate with stakeholders, and provide services to women in the court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration,

court system with the goal of diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. (b) The services offered by the program shall address the following areas: (1) Trauma and mental health treatment; (2) Family support, including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4)

including parenting, education, and relationship improvement; (3) Life-skills training; (4) Education and vocational training; (5) Domestic violence prevention; (6) Medical services and health education; (7) Substance abuse detection, prevention, and treatment; (8) Mentoring; and (9) Housing support. " PART III SECTION 3. (a) There shall be established within the third

SECTION 3. (a) There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program. The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot

be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. court pilot program should: (A) Continue as a pilot program; (B) Expand to include additional participants; (C) Provide additional services; or (D) Be discontinued. SECTION 5. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 or so much thereof as may be

and the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program established pursuant to section 3 of this Act. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. PART IV SECTION 6. This

the purposes of this Act. PART IV SECTION 6. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025; provided that part III shall be repealed on June 30, 2027. Report Title: Judiciary; Women's Court Pilot Program; Reports; Appropriations Description: Permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit. Establishes

establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit. Establishes a temporary two-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. Requires reports. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular

D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Madam and Sir: Your Committee on Conference on the disagreeing vote of the House of Representatives to the amendments proposed by the Senate in H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL

H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," having met, and after full and free discussion, has agreed to recommend and does recommend to the respective Houses the final passage of this bill in an amended form. The purpose of

of this bill in an amended form. The purpose of this measure is to (1) Make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent; (2) Establish and appropriate funds for a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; and (3) Require the

Kona division of the Third Circuit; and (3) Require the Judiciary to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Fifth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit. Your Committee on Conference

Hilo division of the Third Circuit. Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by: (1) Codifying the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit within the Hawaii Revised Statutes, rather than the Session Laws of Hawaii; (2) Requiring the Judiciary to be responsible for providing mental health services under

Judiciary to be responsible for providing mental health services under the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; (3) Changing the duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit from three years to two years; (4) Appropriating $514,900

Circuit from three years to two years; (4) Appropriating $514,900 for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 for fiscal year 2026-2027 for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the Women's Court Pilot

drug court probation supervisor position for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; (5) Deleting language that would have required the Judiciary to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court

the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Fifth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit; (6) Changing the effective date to July 1, 2025; (7) Changing the sunset date for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third

Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit to June 30, 2027; and (8) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style. As affirmed by the record of votes of the managers of your Committee on Conference that is attached to this report,

your Committee on Conference that is attached to this report, your Committee on Conference is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Final Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 727, H.D.

in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 2, C.D. 1.
